Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs propose a broad program of research in theoretical physics which aims to extend the recent advances in string theory, particle physics and cosmology, and to apply them to ongoing experimental programs. One of the most important tools for understanding Gauge Theories is the connection between Semiclassical Gravity in anti-deSitter Space (AdS) and the correlation functions of the conformal invariant gauge field theory that lives on the boundary of the Space (CFT), namely the AdS/CFT correspondence. In particular, they plan to continue to study the dualities between gauge and string theories. They intend to both deepen the insight into the origins of these dual relations and the reasons for their success as well as broaden the scope of their physical applications. The intend to study, in this framework, the confinement problem (why we don't find quarks in a detectro) and hadronic spectra, inflationary cosmology and cosmic strings. New areas will be in the areas of particle model building beyond the Standard Model which display Supersymmetry breaking, understanding the dynamics of the Quark-Gluon Plasma and other aspects of many-body physics. An important new component of the group?s research activity will be field theoretic particle model building and LHC (large Hadron collider) physics. The group plans to develop new tools for LHC data analysis that will be crucial in identifying new physics. This will be based on a mass-shell approach to analyzing the data which is free from theoretical bias. The group will be involved in collaborations and exchanges of ideas between particle phenomenologists, experimentalists and string theorists, which they hope will facilitate the discoveries at the LHC. The group will also will pursue other interesting applications of Quantum Field Theory including the physics of heavy-flavored baryons, and turbulence.
The broader impacts of this project is to prepare post-docs, graduate students, as well as advanced undergraduates, to do successful research in theoretical physics. The group is involved in organizing and lecturing at summer schools, organizing and giving public lectures, and informing the general public about recent research advances. The group is in the process of expanding these outreach activities to include lecturing at minority High Schools and Junior colleges. The group runs the PITP summer school which has a special program of outreach to women and minority graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modern Theoretical Physics is an exciting field. Among its goals is building formal connections between seemingly disparate theories. A relatively recent, and very surprising connection is between gravitational theories, such as Einstein's General Relativity, and gauge quantum field theory models akin to theories which comprise the Standard Model of particle physics. In the latter, the fluctuating degrees of freedom do not include the metric of space-time. The best tested examples of such gauge-gravity duality include gravitational theories in the negatively curved space-time known as anti-de Sitter space, which are related to field theories with special symmetries under scaling of coordinates called conformal field theories. One of the major accomplishments funded by this grant has been a precise formulation of the gauge quantum field theory in three dimensions (two spatial and one time) which corresponds to a gravitational theory called M-theory. To correspond precisely to the quantum field theory, the M-theory is studied in a curved space-time which is anti-de Sitter space times a 7-dimensional compact space (the simplest example of the latter is the round 7-dimensional sphere).

The gauge-gravity duality, including black holes in anti-de Sitter space, has provided valuable tools for gaining intuition about strongly interacting many-body systems, including high-temperature superconductors. The development of  "holographic superconductivity" funded by this grant, has had considerable impact.


Among the tools used in testing the gauge-gravity correspondence is the ability to perform exact calculations in certain 3-dimensional quantum field theories when they are studied on a round 3-dimensional sphere. Calculations of some quantities can then be reduced to finite dimensional N-fold integrals. When N becomes large, efficient techniques have been developed for approximating the integrals, which confirmed the exact correspondence with the M-theory.


These studies led to a general conjecture that a certain quantity computed from a conformal field theory on the 3-dimensional sphere decreases under coarse-graining operations known as the Renormalization Group. This conjectured "F-theorem" has since then undergone many consistency checks. It was shown to have connections with quantum entanglement which is an inherent feature of any quantum theory. Using such connections, other researchers have proposed a proof of the F-theorem.

The grant has also funded research on particle theory in the era of the Large Hadron Collider. In particular, various propoperites of the Higgs boson were investigated in the wake of its long-awaited discovery. Various possibilities for particle physics beyond the Standard Model were studied as well.

   
Notable progress in other directions has included studies of instabilities of quantum field theory in time-dependent backgrounds that are used in building cosmological models. The quantum theory of black holes continues to challenge researchers, and this grant has funded new investigations prompted by a suggestion that the black hole event horizon may be shrouded by a "firewall." This suggestion, which has been analyzed and criticized in research funded by this grant, could have dramatic implications for the unification of Einstein's General Relativity with quantum mechanics.

An important role in research on these cutting edge issues has been played by junior researchers. The training and mentoring of new generations of successful theoretical physicists has been perhaps the most important broader impact of the research.
